awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small:  Collaborative Research: Harnessing Network Coding Gains in Multi-Rate Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Network coding brings the promise of increased wireless network capacity by decreasing the overall number of
transmissions. In practice however, many challenges remain in realizing the gains from network coding. In particular
the interactions between network coding and transmission rate control have not been carefully studied to date.
While transmission at higher rates favor a capacity increase, they can diminish overhearing possibilities, a key requirement
of network coding.
This proposal considers the problem of transmission rate control and network coding in a holistic
way. A framework that examines the interdependencies between the use of network coding and multiple transmission
rates with respect to various functions  spanning the link and routing layers, is developed.


The following tasks are being undertaken: (i) Design a network-coding aware transmission rate control module
that allows nodes to transmit at the high bit rates while at the same time facilitating network coding.
(ii) Design a set of functions at the link and routing layers that provide the best trade-offs between applying
network coding and controlling interference and network congestion
(iii) Implement and extensively evaluate a unified framework combining all of our functional modules on wireless testbeds.

The proposed research is tightly knit with  new education programs by establishing wireless teaching
laboratories and introduce cross-disciplinary courses that bridge the physical and higher layers.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, researchers at Penn State and UC Riverside, in collaboration with researchers from AT&T the University of Thessaly worked to advance the theory and algorithms applied to network coding to improve overall network performance.  Network coding has been previously proposed as an alternative to the conventional store-and-forward routing paradigm for data delivery in networks such as the Internet. When deployed in a multi-rate wireless network, such as popular WiFi networks, network coding has to interact with rate adaptation.  One must use care when selecting the transmission rate to use. While prior work all aimed at reducing the number of packets transmitted over a network, our work examined two goals jointly: maximizing the performance of the network while improving its efficiency by judiciously applying network coding.  

 

We analyzed the performance of network coding for a small set of scenarios representative of common topologies in a network that lead to coding opportunities.

Based on this analysis, we developed our Network Coding aware Rate Selection (NCRS) algorithm. Our results showed that in a multi-hop wireless network, network coding with NCRS achieves up to 24% more gain over routing than network coding with other rate selection algorithms.

 

We then extended our work to look at general policies for transmission using network coding, and implementing a system to obtain experimental results. We designed a distributed framework that (a) facilitates the choice of the best rate on each link while considering the need for overhearing and (b) dictates the choice of which decoding recipient will acknowledge the reception of an encoded packet. We fully implement our system on real hardware and demonstrated its applicability and performance gains via proof-of- concept experiments on our wireless testbed. We show that our framework yields throughput gains of up to 390% as compared to what is achieved in a rate-unaware network coding framework.

 

Finally, we adapted network coding to an environment in which nodes have only intermittent backhaul connectivity, and must use peer-to-peer links and backhaul links with great efficiency.  This type of scenario can occur in very rural environment, or in search-and-rescue or tactical military environments.  We introduced a packet exchange protocol for single-hop wireless packet transmission with network coding between mobile wireless nodes. We developed an algorithm that focuses on encoding packets in a way to achieve the highest possible transmission savings depending on the distribution of packets in the receivers. We derived a theoretical analysis of the upper bound of savings achievable with network coding, and show how the optimal number of wireless nodes for peer to peer data exchange can be estimated. We showed our algorithm may achieve a delay reduction for the exchange of data between mobile nodes by 33.2% on average compared to the current state of the art for data exchange in a military network.
